advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN THE KITCHEN...</strong></font><br><blockquote>A TO-7 in the kitchen? For sure it makes smile the woman!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LIFLEAT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GOLDSTAR 3DO MODEL ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://members.aol.com/djswaggle/3doad.html" target="_blank">3DO ads</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The family advice"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEI BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - FEB.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IBM T-SHIRT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Last sales in the UK. At the same time, a Commodore VIC-20 cost £139 and a Commodore 64 cost $229</blockquote>

computer.description:
This machine was the first Macintosh clone in the whole world.
In Brazil it is almost unknown and there are people who doubt its existence, but it really did exist! This computer almost started a commercial war between Brazil and the United States. Apple persuaded the U.S. government to use everything it could against the Brazilian clone makers (increases in import taxes for brazilian products such as orange juice, shoes, etc.) until this machine was no longer made.
Brazil had a tradition since the beginning of the 80's of cloning computers without permission from the original brand owners (see the lawsuit moved by Sinclair against Microdigital). Apple had so far tolerated brazilian clones of the Apple II, but not this time...
There were differences between this machine and genuine Macs: Some of Unitron's macs had keyboards with black keys, some others had grey keys. Some versions had a disc drive with a button to eject the disc, others were like the original Mac and had no button in its disc drive.
The end of making Brazilian Mac clones may have been not good for Apple in the long run since it opened the doors of Brazilian market to PC clones that didn't have such restrictions.
Thanks to Ernesto Hublard from Brazil for information. _______________________
computer.name: Mac 512

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE & UNITRON</strong></font><br><blockquote>Side by side, the original Apple Macintosh, and the Unitron copy.<br> The original Apple keyboard is here replaced with a large PC-AT-like keyboard from DataDesk International, compatible with the original (128K to Plus) Mac<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jecel Assumpcao Jr</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUAL FDD VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>There could have been a small Unitron production of this dual FDD version. <br> The patch was really ugly (see 'Unitron label' picture)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UNITRON LABEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice also the ugly patch of this dual FDD version. A cable is attached to the regular external floppy connector and then doubles back going in through a crack in the case to the floppy near the front.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jecel Assumpcao Jr</b> for information and picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>One can see the solder side of the video and power supply card. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jecel Assumpcao Jr </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The missing chip, close to the 68000 processor, was for the SCSI interface. So, this version wasn't a pure Mac512 clone. <br><br> The small board sitting on center holds the real time clock chip made for Unitron by National. This ended up having a few bugs so the designers needed to add some TTL chips to work around them. This was done by creating a small board with the chip and fixes that would fit into the socket for the chip. <br><br> It is interesting to note how *everything* is socketed in contrast to production Macs where practically nothing was.<br> Another interesting detail are several small light grey boards - these fit into board positions designed for resistor networks. These probably proved hard to buy for the initial production run and were replaced with these boards built using descrete resistors.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jecel Assumpcao Jr </b></p></blockquote>

computer.size: Probably same as the original Mac 512
